Our current system enriches the medical industrial complex for several reasons.
>drug and medical device prices are negotiated by drug companies/manufacturers and individual pharmacies/hospitals, which means they both stand to profit via price inflation (for ex. $600/pill for name brand vs. $2/pill for generic medications, $800 for a pair of crutches, etc.)
Under universal healthcare the government alone negotiates the prices of drugs and medical devices, which means the manufacturers are put under more pressure to charge a fair rate for their goods and services.
>universal healthcare drastically decreases the size of the private healthcare sector which spends ~80%+ on “administrative” costs
“Administrative” costs include the thousands of insurance reviewers whose entire job is to look for ways to NOT pay the customer’s medical bills. That’s why you can get an x-ray that you thought was covered by your plan only to find out 6 months later that “actually your plan doesn’t cover that specific kind of x-ray” and you end up paying $400 out of pocket.

The entire health insurance industry in America is built around gouging customers and overcharging hospitals. Universal healthcare has prevented this in other countries by largely removing the ability to profit off of fucking people over. People complain about stuff like wait times for medical care in other countries but I’d rather wait longer to get my doctor’s appointment than pay $20,000+ out of pocket for cancer treatment. Taxes wouldn’t even need to increase because our tax dollars are currently subsidizing the medical industry more than in any other developed country due to the intentional inefficiency of our current system.

threads.com:
"Cargo cult" means roughly that someone has tried to copy something he has seen, but really does not understand the underlying principle of. And thus, when he makes the copy it wouldn't really work.

In this thread we take examples all over the world when militaries try to emulate something they think is "proper military stuff" and have tried to copy the form, but don't really understand that it wouldn't work. We are not talking about "practicing marching while holding wooden sticks instead of rifles" because that still teaches you how to march.

Picture related is from Ukraine, when Russian occupiers tried to build tank traps as roadblocks, but did so haphazardly from wood.

historical origins: During the WW2, US troops encountered primitive tribes living in pacific islands. These triblas were amazed by the technology and especially "Cargo" - The support material and foodstuffs that the US military had. Cargo came in with flying machines (planes) and seemingly in endless quantities. As US troops left the islands, the locals tried to make a religion out of what they had seen. They copied the arifields and made planes, radio masts and barracks out of wood, hoping they could call "The Cargo" from the heavens once more.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I've heard that most GPS turns off if going over mach 2 and over 20km to prevent people from making ICBMs with them, however, could you make a cruise missile that goes under those speeds in order to get guidance?
all you'd need is an altimeter and said GPS.
there's ready made programs on arduinos for aircraft stabilization and automatic flight path following due to drone enthusiasts.
so all you'd need to do is make one programmed to pitch down once it's about to reach it's destination
how hard could it really be?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This fucking thread I swear.

All US manufactured and most foreign GPS receivers respect COCOM limits and shutdown above 1000 knots and 59k ft of altitude, this feature exists entirely in the receiver software and exists for legal reasons. GPS receivers are actually decently complicated as far as technology goes and chinese chips are not as available as you might think, most people are not interested in bypassing COCOM limits so there's not much reason for a commercial manufacturer to not implement them. You can DIY a receiver but that's a massive pain in the ass.

The real problem here lies in the autopilot, making an RC aircraft that carries a respectable payload is not too simple, and you need a bunch of test flights to tune the autopilot for independent flight. Nevermind the mechanical design and all that. That said, I'd bet a motivated and decently skilled university hobbyist team could put together a weapon for about 100k$.

>>56280874
500lb Mk82 produces a 5-10 meter crater, with a ~100kg/200lb warhead, which is fucking massive for hobbyist shit to begin with, you'd have to hit within a few meters of your target.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Why is US ground force doctrine so asymmetrical?
threads.com:
I find it kinda interesting how asymmetrically US ground forces are doctrinally compared to US Naval and Air doctrine are. US Naval forces are all about being the pure dominator of the battle space. Nobody can challenge a US CSG in a fight other than another CSG. It’s about putting the most amount of force into the field and completely dominating the battle space.

On the other hand US ground doctrine is a lot more asymmetrical. Of course airland battle is the basis of modern US ground war fighting doctrine and was created when the US couldn’t have developed a force superiority on the ground against the USSR. So they focused on an asymmetrical way of fighting, which would aim to disrupt and destroy soviet command and control nodes as a way to cripple the soviet military in time for conventional defenses to be built up and the US’ industrial advantage to take effect.

I find that in life, all of your problems can be divided into things that you can do something about, and things that you can't do anything about.

For the first category, you don't need to worry because you can just do something and actually fix the underlying problem.

For the second category, you don't need to worry because there is literally nothing you can do and worrying won't make any difference.

If you get really good at sorting things into these two buckets and then acting accordingly, even extreme stress is surprisingly easy to manage.

threads.com:
Previous >>56179383
New cover when edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

An all steel pump shotgun should last forever. 12 gauge is only 12,000 psi (9mm is 35,000 psi) and the barrel is smoothbore so the thing is under virtually no stress compared to the amount of steel it is made from.

And if any of the locking surfaces do wear down from just being pumped two million times then you can fix it just by swapping in a new barrel or bolt locking block in most current models.

Shotguns are some of the most durable, affordable, and simple machines out there. One of the reasons they are so cheap is because even the ones from 1897 are still around and work fine. We literally just have too many shotguns for them to be worth any money. Even an old J.C. Higgins shotgun from 1950 will only sell for around $200 today, even though they are exquisitely made compared to modern stuff, just because every cheap sears shotgun that ever existed still exists.

Shotguns last forever.

threads.sub: What is the best weapon to use to break your arm on a budget?
threads.com:
Asking for a friend.
Ideally, you'd want it to be a clean break with minimal splintering, so wailing on it with a small hammer is probably a terrible idea, but completely snapping the bone is going to be really painful and carries the risk of just outright killing you from shock and blood loss, so dropping a large rock or a dumbbell on it is also going to be a terrible idea.
You could just try loading a single round of a high-powered shotgun or rifle and just try shooting it one-handed; but that could be really expensive as you might accidently break your gun in the attempt, which would just be absolutely terrible.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56285939
Aircraft would be very limited in use, but missiles and artillery would be extremely effective due to the increased range and the lethality of shrapnel against pressurized suits/habs.
Additionally all ground vehicles would have to be some form of electric as there is no oxygen for internal combustion engines.

Ordinary small arms would be highly effective at short to intermediate ranges, but it is worth noting that armor could also be made thicker without being encumbering due to the lower gravity.
Guns would also overheat faster since there is less air to convect heat away, but it probably wouldn't change the outcome too much.

>>56282990
Western optics are a no brainer. Theres no argument for russian optics. Side rail is also a trivial matter. There are actually 4,5 or more companies making SVD spec picatinny side mounts. Nothing modular like RS regulate though. I think the SAG side rail (not the chassis) is one of the better side rails. The chassis is also good though and I think they make them in MLAWK now. The problem with the military SVD (my wife) is that 24" pencil barrel. This is the most glaring issue in 2022. Dragunov was tasked to make the gun as long as the PU mosin, so the barrel is skinny to keep it light which was also a requirement. The compromise is not worth it from 2022 perspective where 16, 18, and 20" barrels are most popular for 308 platforms. A thicker barrel is almost entirely worth the detrackors. Im not sure what advancements in fast burning powder are available for 54r. But I think the most popular SVD barrels are 24" (SVD) 22" (SVDS and SVDM) and 20" (Tigr) but the tigr is also available in the other two, and maybe more perhaps. People kvetch about the rim, but the rim is a non issue, its the lack of bullet availability like 308 has.
An SVD that could give an AR10 a run for its money could be like
Polymer SVD stock
Side mount
Good quality glass (2000 minimum)
Mount 1 - LAM like a ctf2 kijiji mounted on the side rail behind the red dot, wire it with a switch to a velcro pad you can hit with your shooting thumb. acro? T2? 507k? AEMS? Something light oz equal lbs etc. Riser for the red dot for heads up shooting
Mount 2 - Good quality glass (minimum 2000) and a good unibody mount
Polymer handguards
54r mags with +5 extension
Bipod cutout picatinny adapter, QD pictainny bipod
18" heavy barrel, repin the SVDS flash hider and front sight block
Barrel clamp mount, Picatinny lightbar, arisaka/malkoff 600 series white light, with a surefire ST09 that goes to a velcro pad on handguard
